Multi-class Classification

Liyuan Hu

2021/5/31

Source: ../vignettes/MultiClassification.Rmd
MultiClassification.Rmd

Multi-class Classification

When the response falls into only two classes, we have logistic regression, When the number of classes is more than 2, we call it Multi-class Classification.

Multi-class Classification with abess Package

We shall conduct Multi-class Classification on an artificial dataset for demonstration. The generate.data() function provides a simple way to generate suitable for this task. The assumption behind is the response vector following a multinomial distribution.

library(abess)
n <- 100
p <- 20
support.size <- 3
dataset <- generate.data(n, p, support.size, family = "multinomial")
head(dataset$y)
## [1] 1 0 2 1 0 0
dataset$beta
##           [,1]     [,2]     [,3]
##  [1,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [2,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [3,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [4,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [5,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [6,] 84.67713 92.93448 75.47809
##  [7,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [8,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
##  [9,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
## [10,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000
## [11,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000

## [15,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000

## [20,]  0.00000  0.00000  0.00000

To carry out sparse mutli-task learning, you can call the abess() function with family specified to mguassian. Here is an example.

abess_fit <- abess(dataset[["x"]], dataset[["y"]], 
                   family = "multinomial", tune.type = "cv")

coef(abess_fit, support.size = abess_fit$support.size[which.min(abess_fit$tune.value)])
## [[1]]
